citations.narrative:
Several enclosures containing waterfowl have pools that are not large enough for the birds. The affected birds include 2
black swans, 2 Egyptian geese, 1 domestic goose, and 2 Cape Barren geese. Although each enclosure does have small,
clean pools, the size and depth are not large enough for the animals to conduct some normal waterfowl behaviors. Not
providing large enough water areas could result in behavioral concerns and/or the animals’ inability to conduct normal
grooming and preening activities, which could impact their health.
The regulations state that primary enclosures housing wading and aquatic birds must contain a pool or other aquatic area
(e.g., ponds, waterfalls, fountains, and other water features) and a dry area that allows easy ingress or egress of the pool
or other aquatic area. Pools and other aquatic areas must be of sufficient surface area and depth to allow each bird to
make normal postural and social adjustments, such as immersion, bathing, swimming, and foraging, with adequate
freedom of movement and freedom to escape from aggression demonstrated by other birds in the enclosure. Correct by
20December2023.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The required Bird Environmental Enrichment Program (BEEP) was not available for review during this inspection. Not
having a completed BEEP, approved by the Attending Veterinarian, available for review could result in inadequate
enrichment for the birds, which could impact their normal behavioral and environmental activities.
The regulations state that exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment
enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the attending
veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations in this subpart and with currently accepted professional
standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides. This plan must be made available to APHIS
upon request. Correct by 15November2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.153(c) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Several enclosures containing waterfowl have pools that are not large enough for the birds. The affected birds include 2 
black swans, 2 Egyptian geese, 1 domestic goose, and 2 Cape Barren geese. Although each enclosure does have small, 
clean pools, the size and depth are not large enough for the animals to conduct some normal waterfowl behaviors. Not 
providing large enough water areas could result in behavioral concerns and/or the animals’ inability to conduct normal 
grooming and preening activities, which could impact their health.  
 
The regulations state that primary enclosures housing wading and aquatic birds must contain a pool or other aquatic area 
(e.g., ponds, waterfalls, fountains, and other water features) and a dry area that allows easy ingress or egress of the pool 
or other aquatic area. Pools and other aquatic areas must be of sufficient surface area and depth to allow each bird to 
make normal postural and social adjustments, such as immersion, bathing, swimming, and foraging, with adequate 
freedom of movement and freedom to escape from aggression demonstrated by other birds in the enclosure. Correct by 
20December2023. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The required Bird Environmental Enrichment Program (BEEP) was not available for review during this inspection. Not 
having a completed BEEP, approved by the Attending Veterinarian, available for review could result in inadequate 
enrichment for the birds, which could impact their normal behavioral and environmental activities.  
 
The regulations state that exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment 
enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the attending 
veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations in this subpart and with currently accepted professional 
standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides. This plan must be made available to APHIS 
upon request. Correct by 15November2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.

n
